nodes.text: The impact of retirement savings policies on total wealth accumulation depends on whether they change behavior via active choice or passive (automatic) choice

Two-type conceptual model: agents are active savers who optimize and respond to price subsidies, or passive savers who set fixed pension contributions and respond mainly to automatic contributions; comparative statics imply diﬀerent predictions for automatic contributions vs price subsidies

Data and institutional context: administrative panel for Denmark 1995-2009 with 41 million person-year observations on flows into retirement accounts and taxable account wealth; Danish pensions include employer DC, individual DC, capital vs annuity accounts, and a government DB plan

Research design using firm-switch variation: identify causal eﬀect of employer automatic contributions on individual saving by studying savings changes when workers switch firms with diﬀerent employer pension contribution rates

Evidence from firm-switch design: a DKr 1 increase in employer contribution raises total pension contributions by about 0.94 DKr and raises total saving by about 0.78 DKr (pass-through to pensions ~94.9%, to total saving ~77.7%), implying most workers are passive with respect to employer contributions and that automatic contributions substantially raise total saving

Research design using government mandated savings plan (MSP): regression discontinuity at income eligibility cutoff for 1998 MSP that forced 1% of earnings into retirement accounts for eligible workers

Evidence from MSP RD: MSP increased total pension contributions with pass-through to pensions estimated about 84.5% and pass-through to total saving near or above 100% in threshold estimates, showing mandated automatic contributions increase total saving even for previously voluntary savers
Research design for price subsidies: diﬀerence-in-diﬀerences and MPS comparisons around the 1999 reduction in the capital pension tax subsidy for individuals in the top income tax bracket

Evidence from subsidy reform: 1999 cut in capital pension subsidy caused a 48% decline in capital pension contributions driven by about 19% of prior contributors who actively reoptimized; about 57 cents of each DKr moved to annuity pensions (within-retirement crowd-out), and roughly 99 cents of DKr moved from taxable accounts into retirement accounts (crowd-out of taxable saving), implying each DKr of subsidy spending generates near zero net new saving (point estimate near 0.01 DKr new saving; 95% CI upper bound about 0.28 DKr)

Heterogeneity evidence linking active vs passive: active savers are concentrated among wealthier, older, and financially trained individuals and new contributors; active savers respond to price subsidies and are more likely to oﬀset automatic contributions, while passive savers do not respond to subsidies but increase total saving when automatic contributions occur

Conclusion: automatic contributions (employer or mandated) are more eﬀective than price subsidies at raising total wealth because (1) subsidies induce relatively few to respond, (2) responding individuals largely shift assets across accounts generating substantial crowd-out, and (3) subsidies do not raise saving of passive individuals who are least prepared for retirement; policy implication favors automatic enrollment/mandates over subsidies to increase savings

Assumption: the two-type active vs passive framework is a reduced-form maintained to interpret reduced-form pass-through and crowd-out estimates; estimates of fraction active are interpreted under this binary approximation but results are robust to more general behavior
